description: On May 6, the Congregatio de Institutione Catolica announced that Ecclesiastical Universities should finish the year using videoconferencing and other distance learning technologies.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type: Closure and Regulation of Schools
type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
institution_status: Higher education institutions allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Full remote distance learning,Special provisions exist for how teaching is done which applies to all teachers,Other conditions not listed above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 15, the Congregation for Catholic Education instructed Ecclesiastical Universities to return to in person instruction for the upcoming school year. UPDATE: While Universities were put largely online through the Spring 2020 semester, schools are now instructed to reopen and hold classes in person as much as possible.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: May 23, 2020, the Vatican announced  that all visitors to the Vatican museums will be subject to temperature checks. "A medical and health team from Italy’s Misericordie volunteer group and the Vatican’s Health and Hygiene Department will ensure every need during the opening hours."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type: Health Monitoring
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 26, 2020, the Vatican donated 35 ventilators to 13 different countries. Four for Haiti, two for the Dominican Republic, two for Bolivia, four for Brazil, three for Colombia, two for Ecuador and three for Honduras, three were sent to Mexico, four to Venezuela, two to Cameroon, two to Bangladesh, two to Ukraine and two to Zimbabwe (through the local Episcopal Conference).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: Health Resources
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 3, the Dicastery for the Promotion of Integral Human Development announced that Pope Francis "has donated 25,000 Euros to the World Food Programme (WFP)." "It is 'an immediate expression of the Holy Father’s closeness' to people affected by the pandemic and those 'engaged in essential services in favour of the poor."
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type: Health Resources
target_geog_level: An international organization (e.g. World Health Organization)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 3, the Dicastery for the Promotion of Integral Human Development announced that Pope Francis "has donated 25,000 Euros to the World Food Programme (WFP)." This was a one time donation. UPDATE: As it was a one time donation, the policy is now complete.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: Health Resources
target_geog_level: An international organization (e.g. World Health Organization)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Vatican announced on August 3 that "Vatican employees and workers who have contact with the public are being tested for the antibodies for COVID-19."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type: Health Testing
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: March 30, 2020, the Dicastery for Promoting Integral Human Development at the direction of Pope Francis "has established a Vatican COVID-19 Commission to take up the Pope’s concern through the activities of five Working Groups, which are: acting now for the future; looking to the future with creativity; communicating hope; seeking common dialogue and reflections; supporting to care."
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)

description:
As of March 10 in Vatican City "the pharmacy and the Annona supermarket remain open, but with restricted entry." 
At the pharmacy, entrance is limited and shields have been put up to protect employees and shoppers. Similar measures have been put in place at the supermarket. "These measures will remain in force, unless further indications are given, until 3 April 2020."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: Restriction and Regulation of Businesses
institution_cat: Essential Businesses
institution_status: This type of business  ("Supermarkets/grocery stores") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
In coordination with the measures launched by the Italian authorities, a number of measures were adopted March 8, 2020 to prevent the spread of COVID-19, to be observed in the Dicasteries and other entities of or related to the Holy See, and in the Governorate of Vatican City State. These measures include the precautionary closure, until 3 April 2020, of the Vatican Museums, the Excavation Office, the Museum of the Pontifical Villas and the museum centres of the Pontifical Basilicas.
These measures will remain in force, unless further indications are given, until 3 April 2020. UPDATE: The Holy See has decided to extend until 13 April inclusive the measures adopted so far to avoid the spread of the coronavirus, in coordination with the provisions issued by the Italian authorities on 1 April 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description:
As of March 10 Saint Peter’s Square and Basilica are closed to guided tours and tourists. The pharmacy and the Annona supermarket remain open, but with restricted entry. The mobile unit of the Vatican Post Office in Saint Peter’s Square, the two sale points of the Libreria Editrice Vaticana, the Photographic Service of L’Osservatore Romano, which will remain accessible online, and the clothing warehouse will remain closed.
The canteen for employees will be closed to the public from March 11, when a meal delivery service will be activated at the request of the various bodies and entities of the Holy See and Vatican City State.
These measures will remain in force, unless further indications are given, until 3 April 2020. UPDATE: The Holy See has decided to extend until 13 April inclusive the measures adopted so far to avoid the spread of the coronavirus, in coordination with the provisions issued by the Italian authorities on 1 April 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_cat: Non-Essential Government Services
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government

description: As of March 10, Vatican City will close the two sale points of the Libreria Editrice Vaticana, the publishing house of the state. One of these sale points is located in the city, in Piazza San Pietro and the other is located in Rome in Piazza Pio XII. These two sale points will remain closed through May 3. UPDATE: The two locations of the publishing house, closed through April 13, will now remain closed through May 3.

description: Vatican City has announced that "the canteen for employees will be closed to the public from tomorrow, March 11, when a meal delivery service will be activated at the request of the various bodies and entities of the Holy See and Vatican City State." This policy will continue through May 3. UPDATE: The canteen, closed through April 13, will remain closed through May 3.

description: On March 19, 2020, the Vatican announced the "the suspension...of all court activities in progress at the judicial offices of the Vatican City State, as well as the related forfeiture and limitation periods." The courts will remain suspended until May 3 inclusive. UPDATE: The courts, closed through April 13, will now remain closed through May 3.

description: As of March 10 the Vatican has closed St. Peter's Square and Basilica to guided tours and tourists. The Square and Basilica reopen on May 18. UPDATE: Recently scheduled to reopen on May 3, the Square and Basilica will now reopen (with health precautions in place) on May 18.

description: The Vatican Museums, the Excavation Office, the Museum of the Pontifical Villas and the museum centres of the Pontifical Basilicas will now open on June 1. UPDATE: The Vatican Museums and Pontifical Villas, initially slated for reopening on April 3, will now open on June 1.

description: The Vatican Apostolic Archive closed to visitors on March 6. The Archive reopens on June 1. Scholars "cannot exceed 15 persons per day" and "the opening timetable will be from 8:30 to 12:30 until further notice." The Archive will close for its scheduled summer break following June 26. UPDATE: The Archive, which originally had no reopening date, will now reopen on June 1 with health measures in place and close for its customary summer break on June 26.

description: On March 10, the Vatican closed "the mobile unit of the Vatican Post Office in Saint Peter’s Square." The unit has reopened June 1. UPDATE: The closure of the office was extended through May 3, but the office has now officially reopened on June 1.

description: In Vatican City, in keeping with the norms of hygiene and physical distance, visitors to the Vatican Museums will be allowed in only with a facemask. Facemasks will also be required for visitors at the Pontifical Villas. This will take effect upon the opening of the Museums, June 1, and the Villas, June 6.
